awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Practical Leakage Resilience: Provable Side-Channel Resistance for Embedded Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The security of pervasive computing devices relies on cryptographic engines which are usually considered the most trusted part of the system. An immanent threat to embedded cryptographic engines are physical attacks. Practical countermeasures against physical attacks are not completely fail-safe and overly expensive for most applications. Theoretical approaches, however, still tend to have imperfect leakage models and wrong or impractical assumptions about the abilities of cryptographic sub-primitives. Yet, the theoretical concepts of leakage resilience, which have been mostly disregarded by practitioners, carry a great potential to construct cryptographic primitives that resist physical attacks and allow for more resource-efficient implementations.

The project investigates solutions for basic cryptographic services that are (i) secure in the presence of physical attacks and (ii) are comparable in performance and costs to state-of-the-art implementations of cryptography. This is achieved by enhancing the concepts of leakage resilience to make them applicable in the constrained regimes of embedded pervasive systems. Theoretical concepts are advanced and brought into practice by actual implementation. Practical evaluation uncovers remaining weaknesses in the currently used leakage models. By combining the advantages of both approaches ? a thorough practical evaluation of the applied methods and the well-defined leakage-resilience of the theoretical approaches ? stronger, more reliable, and practical solutions are derived. Besides an increased security for the wide range of embedded products, the findings give valuable feedback to both theoretic cryptographers and practical security architects.  

Only security solutions that are leakage resilient, withstand practical evaluation and match economic expectations guarantee a widespread use and hence more secure pervasive systems.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we explored new ways to build cryptographic services that are secure in the presence of physical attacks and are comparable in performance and costs to state-of-the-art implementations of cryptography.

We analyzed several alternative cryptosystems that feature better leakage behavior than common systems such as RSA and AES. We showed that systems limiting the re-use of secret keys such as Merkle trees for signatures are a great way of achieving a high level of leakage resistance while requiring only minimal implementation overhead. For such schemes, we proposed new ways of quantifying leakage to show achieved security levels. We also revealed remaining issues by exposing new attacks for implementations with too little protection.

A second explored direction was the protection of prevailing cryptosystems through theoretically sound protected implementation techniques. We focused our efforts on threshold implementation and secure multiparty computation. Both methods are theoretically sound and also achieve high resistance to practical attacks at a reasonable cost. Our contributions include showing how to minimize overheads of threshold implementation, resulting in some of the smallest side channel protected hardware implementations. Another direction was showing how to integrate fault and leakage protection using multiparty computation techniques.

All results have been verified through reference implementations in embedded software or hardware. We also performed leakage analysis of these reference implementations to practically validate the claimed security levels. Developed implementations have been made available as open source. Insights and findings have been shared with the research community through several publications and have been integrated into the curriculum of existing and new courses in the security program, equipping our graduates with higher awareness of security risks and knowledge of how to build more secure systems.

By finding better methods to protect systems against physical attacks at reasonable cost, this project has contributed to making digital devices more secure for wide deployment in many devices and systems used in commercial and industrial applications and even critical infrastructures.
